document.text: Yorktown.Notwithstanding an al most continual downpour of rain the celebration here of the one hundred and twenty-ninth anniversary of the surrender of Lord Cornwallis to Gen eral Washington at Yorktown on Oc tober 19, 1781, was a success. The program was observed outside except the literary exercises, which had to be held in the Courthouse, and not in the park surrounding the monument. Fully 5,000 people from all parts of the Virginia Peninsula and many from afar were gathered to join in the cele bration. The houses and stores of the old town were appropriately decorated, the French flag being frequently noted At 1 oclock a military parade started, made up by the coast artillery camps, a band from Fort Monroe, a battalion of sailors and a band from Norfolk Navy Yard, a battalion of sailors from the United States scout cruiser Bir mingharti and a company from the revenue cutters Onandaga and Apache The civic division consisted of 250 men and women on horseback, which cav alcade included 40 members of the or der of Red Men of York county. Aboul 200 students of William and Mary Col lege, at Williamsburg, also formed s part of the civic division. Roanoke.M. M. Spence, yard con ductor for the Virginia Railway in this city, was murdered by an unidentified man in the western edge of town, and, although bloodhounds were on the scene two hours after the killing, they failed to take the scent, and, so far. there Is no clue to the Identity of the conductors slayer. Spence was seen by fellow workmen 15 minutes before his dead body was discovered in a poo of blood with the juglar vein severed and the face and hAnds cut into rib bons. One man says he saw Spence and another man, whom he did not know, walking together on the rail road yard earlier in the day, and that they were quarreling. There was evi dence of a terrible struggle. Spence was married two months ago to Miss Alice Himes, who was stenographer to the city engineer. He was 25 years old and popular. Harrisonburg.Fire resulting from an exploding lamp destroyed the six- room dwelling of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wood, near Spring Creek, Rockingham county, and now parents and seven children, the eldest 14, are left home less and penniless. Mrs. Wood went to bed upstairs, leaving five of the children studying their lessons in the kitchen, where the explosion occurred. Mr. Wood, who was visiting a neigh bor, rushed home with 75 people of the community, who formed a bucket brig ade, but in 30 minutes the residence was In ashes. By the hardest sort of work the fire fighters managed to save the henhouse and washhouse near the dwelling. Mr. Wood is a workingman and had no insurance on the place. Suffolk. Elmer Dan iel was arrested a few days ago on tht charge of holding up A. V. Sturgeon with a shotgun. After being locked up Daniel drank of a bottle ol laudanum which he had concealed in his stocking at that time to carry out his plan of self-destruction at the next favorable opportunity. Waterman, ol New York city, has presented the town with a school site, valued at 5,000, on the well-known Waterman property, in the western suburbs of Harrisonburg, and a new 15,000 structure will be ready for occupancy by September, 1911. The crowded condition forced the school board to hunt for a site to build a new school. In response to a letter asking for a price of the Wat erman site, the owner generously pre sented the land to the town, with the proviso that it should always be used for public purposes. Lynchburg.It has been ascertained that Leonard Campbell, the 4-year-old boy who died in a hospital here, was a victim of anthrax, a cattle disease which seldom attacks a human being. This was discovered by a microscop ical examination of the blood after death. Dr. Lile, the physician in charge of the case, will make a com plete report of it to a leading medical journal. Anthrax was prevalent among cattle near the home of the boy. Winchester.While climbing a 10- foot pole to reach for a chain attached to an electric street lamp, Thomas Clem, the 15-year-old son of Jerry Clem, was electrocuted. The moment he touched the wire chain several women in the neighborhood warned the boy to stay down, but he did not heed their advice. It is supposed that the chain was charged by the hanging wire.

document.text: Washington Special.  A settle ment of the controversy in the Paci fic Coast States arising over the ex clusion of Japanese pupils from pub lic schools has been reached. Mayor Schmitz and the members of the San Francisco school board gave assurance to the President that if the amended bill becomes a law they will abolish the oriental schools in San Francisco and will admit Ja panese pupils to the white schools. These agreements were arrived at after conferences between the Presi dent and his friends in the Senate regarding the Immigration Bill, and after two conferences between Presi dent Roosevelt and Secretary Root on one side and Mayor Schmitz and other visitors from San Francisco on the other. After a conference with the President Mayor Schmitz gave out this statement We have come to a satisfactory understanding upon the assumption that Congress will pass the amend ment to the Immigration Bill intro duced February 13. The filibustering tactics on the Im migration Bill in the Senate were brought to a close by assurances from the White House that there would be no ruling on the practice, inauguarated by South Carolina, of states importing foreign labor. If war should be declared, he said, the Philippines would doubt less be seized by the Japanese, and possibly Hawaii. This could be done before we could reach the scene of action, but no sooner would we ar rive there than we could retake them. Our present navy is amply able to deal with that of the Japan ese and to insure no doubt of the immediate issue in case of a conflict. By this I do not mean that the aavy should not be increased con stantly, for money so spent is the strongest possible insurance of peace sad, as an insurance, well spent.
